children.subject: Thanks for posting. Nice to see another person's take on this.

I think there are 2 skills that need to be developed for DP.

One is to solve the problem via programming. I find this easier. However, its messy, iterative, and takes too long. The other is to solve it via mathematical thinking. (I know these are equivalent in a sense but programming gives you more feedback)

Mathematical thinking can get you the right answer but its easy to overlook some aspect (ex: I wrote the max{ P(i,j) } instead of max { P(i,j) : j < i} )

Solutions can be tested via programming, visual techniques (as you demonstrate nicely in Excel) or mathematical proofs. Sometimes I think I have it right, but I don't.

I'm trying to hone in the math thinking skill.
Updated some of the numbers in 6.20 where I added wrong.
Updated - now includes 6.7 and 6.20, in both the word and excel docs.  I didnt do #19, but everything else is done.

history.content:
Hi All,

I tend to be a visual learner, so I have to map out problems to understand how they work.  In regards to the DP practice problems, I have a Word doc that explains the problem in my own words along with the recurrence / pseudocode, and then an Excel doc that visually shows how the problem works out for an example.

I wasn't planning on making this public, which means that in some cases I don't fully flesh out the problem because I understand it to a point; also I am still working on 3 problems so its not quite done (but if this is helpful for you, check back periodically as I will upload a newer version when I have one available).

(Just a note - I used the word 'deck' to denote the current item being investigated (i.e. 'on deck'); so if 1 <= j <= 5, and we are looping through the array and j is currently 3, Array[3] is what I am calling the 'deck' item)

If you want the Word doc, its here.

If you want the Excel doc, its here.

Its best if you follow along with the pseudocode as you are stepping through the examples.

Thanks and good luck!
-Brent
history.subject: DP Problems, Visualized
